questions.text: Indication for this incision: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open rhinoplasty

 

The image shows an incision along the columella and the nostrils, characteristic of an open rhinoplasty approach. In open rhinoplasty, this type of incision allows the surgeon to lift the skin over the nasal dorsum, providing direct visualization of the underlying bony and cartilaginous structures, including the alar cartilages and nasal bones. This approach is used for making precise adjustments to the shape of the external nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell luc: Caldwell-Luc surgery is a procedure primarily used for accessing the maxillary sinus. It involves making an incision in the gingivobuccal sulcus (inside the mouth) to enter the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall. This approach is not related to nasal dorsum access and does not involve incisions on the external nose.

 

 

Option B. Midfacial degloving: Midfacial degloving is a technique used for the removal of extensive nasopharyngeal tumors, such as juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas (JNA). It involves lifting the facial soft tissues, including the nasal mucosa, through incisions made intraorally. This method provides access to the nasal cavity and maxillary sinus but does not involve an incision like the one shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incision shown in the image is specific to open rhinoplasty, allowing direct access to the nasal structures for reshaping and reconstructive procedures.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6th cranial nerve

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This can be remembered using the" This means that the Superior Oblique muscle is innervated by the 4th cranial nerve, the Lateral Rectus by the 6th cranial nerve, and the rest of the extraocular muscles are innervated by the 3rd cranial nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, but not the lateral rectus.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 4th cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) innervates only the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option D. 7th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) is not involved in eye movement; it primarily controls facial muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve).

questions.text: As per the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, inclusive of overtime? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 60 hours

 

The Factories Act of 1948 permits a maximum of 48 hours of regular work per week, which can be extended up to 60 hours per week with standard overtime.

 

Factories Act – established in 1948:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defence, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maximum work hours per week is 48 hours. With overtime one can extend it upto 60 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is intracapsular but extrasynovial? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Long Biceps Tendon

 

The long head of biceps tendon is a classic example of a structure that is intracapsular (inside the joint capsule) but extrasynovial (outside the synovial membrane). As the tendon passes from the supraglenoid tubercle through the shoulder joint to reach the bicipital groove, it pierces the capsule but remains enveloped by a synovial sheath. This unique anatomical arrangement allows the tendon to pass through the joint while maintaining its own synovial environment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoralis Major - This muscle is completely extracapsular and extrasynovial. It inserts onto the lateral lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus and does not enter the joint capsule at any point.

 

Option C. Popliteus Muscle - While the popliteus tendon does have a complex relationship with the knee joint, it is not truly intracapsular and extrasynovial like the long head of biceps. Its tendon passes beneath the lateral collateral ligament outside the joint capsule. Therefore, part of its tendon is intracapsular, while the question muscle itself is largely extracapsular.

 

Option D. Supraspinatus Tendon - This tendon is part of the rotator cuff and lies outside both the joint capsule and synovial membrane, making it extracapsular and extrasynovial. It passes over the shoulder joint capsule but doesn't penetrate it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The long head of biceps tendon has a unique anatomical position as it travels through the shoulder joint capsule (intracapsular) while remaining outside the synovial cavity (extrasynovial), which has important implications for pathological processes affecting this structure.

questions.text: Examine the histological section provided. Which type of cartilage is shown in the image?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. White fibrocartilage

 

The given image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. This is suggestive of white fibrocartilage.

 

Microscopy of fibrocartilage shows the following:

 

  • Chondrocytes- Round in shape (in tendons they are flattened and elongated)
  • Ground tissue with collagen fibers- Type I collagen fibers
  • Absence of perichondrium

 

Note - White fibrocartilage is dense with collagen fibers (primarily type I collagen), which gives a great tensile strength. It is found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, menisci of the knee, and places where tendons insert into bones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-articular hyaline cartilage: It's a type of hyaline cartilage not involved in joint articulations. The matrix contains a moderate amount of collagen fibers, predominantly type II collagen, making it tough but somewhat flexible. It is found in the respiratory tract (including the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cartilages), growth plates of bones, and the anterior aspect of ribs (costal cartilages).

 

Option B. Articular hyaline cartilage: It is similar in composition to non-articular hyaline cartilage, but specifically lines the surfaces of bones in synovial joints. It covers the ends of bones in synovial joints such as the knee, shoulder, and hip.

 

Option C. Yellow cartilage (Elastic cartilage): It contains elastic fibers and collagen fibers, mainly type II collagen. The elastic fibers give it more flexibility than hyaline cartilage. It is found in the ear pinna (auricle), epiglottis, and auditory (Eustachian) tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Milkman’s fracture is a type of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Pseudofracture

 

Milkman's fracture is a type of pseudofracture found in bone softening disorders such as osteomalacia. These are not true fractures but rather indentations of the cortex due to arterial pulsations. They are also known as Looser's Zone or Umbauzanon. Milkman fractures commonly occur in the neck of femur (NOF) and pubic rami, appearing as radiolucent zones at sites of stress in radiographic imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicular fracture - Milkman's fracture is unrelated to a specific clavicular injury. While pseudofractures can occur in various bones, they are most commonly found in weight-bearing areas like the pubic rami and femoral neck in patients with underlying bone softening disorders.

 

Option C. Humeral fracture - Milkman's fracture is not a type of humeral fracture. Pseudofractures characteristically appear at sites where major blood vessels cross bone, creating pressure points that lead to cortical indentation.

 

Option D. Metacarpal fracture - Milkman's fracture does not refer to metacarpal injuries. These pseudofractures typically affect the axial skeleton and weight-bearing long bones in conditions like osteomalacia, hyperparathyroidism, and neurofibromatosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Milkman's fracture represents a pseudofracture (Looser's Zone) seen in bone softening disorders, primarily osteomalacia, appearing as cortical indentations at sites of arterial pulsation, commonly in the femoral neck and pubic rami.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with disproportionate short stature with increased upper segment: lower segment ratio. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Achondroplasia

 

Achondroplasia is characterized by an increased upper segment to lower segment ratio. Normal US:LS ratio values are:

 

  • At birth: 1.7:1
  • At 3 years: 1.3:1
  • At 7-10 years: 1:1

 

When this ratio is increased, remember the mnemonic RHA:

 

  • R: Rickets
  • H: Hypothyroidism
  • A: Achondroplasia

 

In achondroplasia, FGFR3 gene mutation leads to:

 

  • Short limbed dwarfism with proximal limb shortening
  • Trident hand
  • Motor milestones delayed
  • Large head
  • Obesity
  • Decreased interpedicular distance

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia: Incorrect. This primarily affects spine and epiphyses causing short trunk dwarfism, not increased US:LS ratio.

 

Option C. Alagille syndrome: Incorrect. Features butterfly vertebrae, peripheral pulmonary stenosis and bile duct paucity, but doesn't affect US:LS ratio.

 

Option D. TB spine: Incorrect. Causes vertebral destruction and gibbus deformity but doesn't characteristically alter US:LS ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia presents with an increased upper segment:lower segment ratio due to short limbs with a relatively preserved trunk length. The condition is caused by an FGFR3 gene mutation and is the most common form of disproportionate short stature.

questions.text: All of the following are unpaired anterior branches of the abdominal aorta, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Median sacral artery

 

 

The median sacral artery is not an anterior branch of the abdominal aorta, but rather a terminal branch that arises from the posterior aspect of the aorta at its bifurcation into the common iliac arteries. It descends in the midline anterior to the sacrum and coccyx. This artery is unpaired but is not classified as an anterior branch due to its position and point of origin.

 

The main unpaired anterior branches of the abdominal aorta include the celiac trunk (T12-L1), superior mesenteric artery (L1), and inferior mesenteric artery (L3), which supply the foregut, midgut, and hindgut respectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Celiac trunk - This is indeed an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of T12-L1. It divides into the left gastric, splenic, and common hepatic arteries and supplies the foregut derivatives.

 

Option B. Inferior mesenteric artery - This is an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of L3. It supplies the hindgut derivatives including the left one-third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and upper rectum.

 

Option C. Superior mesenteric artery - This is an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of L1. It supplies the midgut derivatives including the small intestine, cecum, appendix, ascending colon, and right two-thirds of the transverse colon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The abdominal aorta has three major unpaired anterior branches (celiac trunk, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery) that supply the three embryological divisions of the gut, while the median sacral artery is a terminal branch arising from the posterior aspect of the aorta at its bifurcation.

choices.text: Tricuspid valve bulging into Right atria

questions.text: In JVP ‘a ‘wave represents which one of the following? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right atrial contraction

 

Explanation: 

 

The a-wave in the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to atrial contraction. When the right atrium contracts, it causes an increase in pressure that is transmitted backward into the jugular veins, creating the a-wave. This wave appears just before the carotid pulse and first heart sound (S1). The a-wave is one of the most easily visible waves in the JVP examination and is particularly important because its presence confirms that the patient is in sinus rhythm, as it indicates normal atrial contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrial relaxation: Incorrect. Right atrial relaxation is represented by the 'x' descent in JVP, not the 'a' wave.

 

Option C. Tricuspid valve bulging into Right atria: Incorrect. This is represented by the 'c' wave in JVP, which occurs when the tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium during early ventricular systole.

 

Option D. Right atrial filling: Incorrect. Right atrial filling is represented by the 'v' wave in JVP, which occurs during venous return when the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

a-wave in the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to atrial contraction and understand its clinical significance in assessing cardiac rhythm and right heart function.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CPAM


Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) is a congenital lung lesion characterized by multiple cystic spaces within the lungs, often detected through imaging such as CT or X-rays. In this case, the child’s imaging shows a multi-cystic, bubbly appearance with air-filled spaces, which is typical of CPAM. CPAM often presents with recurrent respiratory infections due to the abnormal lung structure. Although the images combine antenatal ultrasound and postnatal imaging, they highlight the congenital nature of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyopneumothorax: This condition involves pus and air within the pleural cavity, usually caused by infection or trauma. It presents with an air-fluid level, often with signs of pleural infection such as fever and chest pain. The multi-cystic appearance seen in the imaging does not match this condition.

 

Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia): CDH involves the herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity, usually on the left side. CDH presents with bowel loops in the chest and displacement of the lung tissue, which is not observed here. The appearance of the lesion on the right side with multiple air-filled cysts rules out CDH.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: A lung abscess is a localized area of necrosis and pus within the lung, often appearing as a round lesion with an air-fluid level. This differs significantly from the bubbly, multi-cystic appearance seen in the imaging, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


CPAM is characterized by multiple cystic, air-filled spaces in the lung and is a congenital lesion that often presents with recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Hyperbilirubinemia refers to an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin is a yellow compound that occurs in the normal catabolic pathway that breaks down heme in red blood cells. There are two types of hyperbilirubinemia based on the type of bilirubin that is elevated: conjugated (direct) and unconjugated (indirect).

 

  • Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia occurs when there is an excess of bilirubin that has not been processed by the liver. This is known as indirect bilirubin. In Gilbert syndrome, there is a reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for converting unconjugated bilirubin into its conjugated form. As a result, patients with Gilbert syndrome have elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin, especially during periods of fasting, illness, or stress.

 

Note - Crigler Najjar Syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder of bilirubin conjugation characterized by severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that can result in bilirubin-induced neurologic dysfunction (BIND).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin Johnson Syndrome: This syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is characterized by defective hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin due to a mutation affecting the transport protein MRP2.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: This leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare, benign condition where there is a mild defect in bilirubin storage and transport.

 

Option C. Biliary atresia: This is a condition in which the bile ducts inside or outside the liver do not have normal openings. This leads to a buildup of conjugated bilirubin and results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, resulting from reduced enzyme activity that impairs the conversion of unconjugated bilirubin to its conjugated form

questions.text: A female patient with dysphagia more for liquids in comparison to solids is likely to have which of the following finding in her barium swallow? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Smooth tapering of lower end

 

In achalasia cardia, there is a selective loss of inhibitory neurons in the lower esophagus, particularly affecting the lower esophageal sphincter. This neuronal loss leads to a characteristic radiological appearance of smooth tapering at the lower end of the esophagus, often referred to as the "bird beak" appearance. The patient experiences dysphagia, with more difficulty swallowing liquids compared to solids due to the impaired esophageal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Irregular filling defect: Typically associated with other esophageal pathologies like tumors or strictures, not characteristic of achalasia.

 

Option B. Rat tail appearance: Classically associated with gastric carcinoma during barium studies. This sign indicates an infiltrative tumor at the pylorus or distal stomach, creating a narrowed, tapered appearance resembling a rat's tail. It is not a characteristic finding in esophageal disorders.

 

Option D. Corkscrew appearance: This radiological sign is typically seen in diffuse esophageal spasm. This is not a characteristic radiological feature of achalasia cardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiological hallmark of achalasia cardia: smooth tapering of the lower esophageal end (bird beak appearance) due to loss of inhibitory neurons.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 37 weeks. She is a known case of heart disease with a prosthetic valve on warfarin. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Switch to LMWH

 

The patient is a 37-week pregnant woman with a known case of heart disease and a prosthetic valve, currently on warfarin. In pregnant patients with prosthetic heart valves, anticoagulation management is crucial to prevent thromboembolic complications. Warfarin is typically avoided in the late third trimester due to the risk of fetal bleeding and other complications during delivery. It is recommended to switch from warfarin to heparin (usually low molecular weight heparin, LMWH) at around 36 weeks of gestation.

 

Since the patient is still on warfarin at 37 weeks, the immediate action is to switch to LMWH to reduce the risks associated with warfarin during labor and delivery. Before planning an induction of labor (IOL) or cesarean section, heparin should be stopped 12-24 hours before the planned delivery to minimize the risk of bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin: Continuing warfarin at this stage is inappropriate because it increases the risk of bleeding for both the mother and the fetus during labor or delivery. Warfarin crosses the placenta and poses significant risks during the peripartum period.

 

Option C. Immediate cesarean: There is no immediate indication for a cesarean section based on her anticoagulation status alone. Cesarean delivery would only be indicated for obstetric reasons. Moreover, performing surgery while the patient is on warfarin increases the risk of severe bleeding complications.

 

Option D. Immediate IOL (Induction of Labor): Immediate induction of labor is not the first step as the patient is still on warfarin, which poses a bleeding risk. Before planning any delivery method, it is essential to switch to heparin and allow a safe window without anticoagulation before proceeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves on warfarin, switch to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) at 36 weeks to reduce the risk of complications during delivery, and stop heparin 12-24 hours before planned delivery.

questions.text: The imaging shows a detailed cross-sectional view of the esophageal wall and surrounding structures. What is the primary use of this imaging modality? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staging of esophageal cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is primarily used for staging esophageal cancer, particularly for T (tumor) and N (nodal) staging. Its high-resolution imaging capabilities allow detailed visualization of the esophageal wall layers and surrounding lymph nodes. However, for M (metastasis) staging, PET-CT remains the investigation of choice, as is true for most cancers.

 

Additional uses of EUS include:

 

  • Assessment of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, particularly gastrinomas in the duodenum
  • Evaluation of biliary microlithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identifying the cause of dysphagia: While EUS can visualize esophageal structures, it's not the primary tool for diagnosing causes of dysphagia. Standard endoscopy and barium studies are more commonly used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Assessing cardiac and aortic pathology: This is done using transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), which is a different procedure where the ultrasound probe faces anteriorly to examine the heart, rather than examining the esophageal wall itself.

 

Option D. Evaluation of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): 24-hour pH monitoring is the standard test for GERD evaluation. EUS is not routinely used for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ultrasound is the investigation of choice for T and N staging of esophageal cancer, while PET-CT is used for M staging.

choices.text: Medial cutaneous nerve of arm
Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm

questions.text: A patient experiences chest pain radiating to the arm. Which nerve can be responsible for the radiating pain? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intercostobrachial nerve

 

The intercostobrachial nerve is responsible for the sensory innervation of the skin of the upper medial aspect of the arm and also partially the chest wall. It is a branch of the second intercostal nerve (T2) and often gets involved in referred pain during conditions like myocardial infarction. The radiating pain from the chest to the arm, particularly in the case of heart attacks, is due to the involvement of the intercostobrachial nerve. This nerve shares dermatomes with the T1-T2 spinal segments, which also receive cardiac sensory fibers, leading to the referred pain in the arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm and provides sensory innervation to the lateral forearm, not typically associated with chest pain radiating to the arm.

 

Option C. Medial cutaneous nerve of arm: This nerve supplies the skin on the medial side of the arm but does not typically carry pain from the chest. It's not usually involved in referred cardiac pain.

 

Option D. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm: This nerve supplies the skin on the medial side of the forearm and is also not typically involved in radiating chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intercostobrachial nerve, originating from T2, is responsible for the sensation in the upper medial arm and can be involved in referred pain from the chest, such as during a myocardial infarction. This nerve is key in understanding the dermatome distribution related to cardiac pain.

questions.text: Which of the following Amino acid needs to be supplied in the diet of patients with Cystathionine beta synthase defect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysteine

 

Cysteine is not typically restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. In fact, cysteine supplementation may be necessary in some cases because CBS deficiency can lead to a decreased ability to convert homocysteine into cysteine. However, this decision is made on an individual basis after assessing the patient's specific needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methionine: Methionine is usually restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. Since methionine is metabolized to homocysteine, limiting dietary methionine intake can help reduce homocysteine levels in these patients.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine is not typically restricted in the diet of CBS-deficient patients. It is not directly related to homocysteine metabolism, so it does not require special dietary adjustments.

 

Option D. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is not supplied in the diet but rather accumulates in the body as a result of CBS deficiency. Managing and reducing elevated homocysteine levels is the primary goal of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) is involved in the synthesis of cysteine from dietary methionine. Cysteine synthesis require methionine, serine and vitamin B6. The reactions are summarized in the diagram:

 

 

So, in case of CBS deficiency there will be no formation of cystathionine and cysteine. so, cysteine becomes essential and needs to be taken in diet.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 291

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Condyloma accuminata

 

  • Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).
  • The main causative agent is HPV-6 and 11.
  • Lesions: Typically, they grow in clusters along a narrow stalk giving it a cauliflower appearance but at times the stalk may be broad and thick
  • Treatment: Cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision or topical use of 5-fluorouracil, trichloro-acetic acid or intralesional interferon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum:

 

  • Caused by a pox virus transmitted by body contact or towels or clothing.
  • It is commonly seen in immunodeficient subject or with HIV infections.
  • The lesions vary in size up to 1 cm, dome shaped, pearly-white in colour and often umbilicated.
  • They are usually multiple and can occur anywhere in the skin and genitalia.
  • Microscopic appearance reveals numerous inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies) in the cytoplasm of the cells with Giemsa stain.
  • Treatment: 
    • Evacuation of caseous material from the nodule under local anaesthetic is done.
    • The floor of the nodule is then treated chemically with ferric sub-sulphate or trichloroacetic acid (85%) solution.
    • Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is applied until a halo of ice is formed around the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Chancroid:

 

  • Chancroid is a bacterial sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by infection with Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may be accompanied by inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

 

 

Option D. Herpes:

 

  • The causative organism is herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 and 2.
  • It is usually transmitted sexually by an infected partner/ oro-genital contact.
  • The incubation period is 2–14 days.
  • Clinical Features: 
    • Initially, red painful inflammatory areas appear commonly on the clitoris, labia, vestibule, vagina, perineum, and cervix.
    • Multiple vesicles appear which progress into multiple shallow ulcers and ultimately heal up spontaneously by crusting.
    • It takes about 3 weeks to complete the process.
    • Inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever, malaise, and headache.
    •  There may be vulvar burning, pruritus, dysuria, or retention of urine.
  • Treatment: Acyclovir

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) are characterized by multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, caused by HPV-6 and 11, and treated with cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision, or topical agents.

 

Ref: Page no 153, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Acute tubular necrosis

questions.text: A patient was undergoing a hysteroscopic removal of a submucosal fibroid, in which a fluid deficit of 2000 mL is estimated in a patient. What is the immediate complication of this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario depicts case of fluid overload, due to which pulmonary edema can develop.

 

  • During hysteroscopy, systemic absorption of uterine distension fluid occurs through open sinuses or vessels.
  • Fluid deficit can be estimated by manual calculation or by use of an automated fluid management system.
  • When using hypotonic solutions (like glycine), the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 1000mL for healthy patients and 750mL for elderly patients or those with medical comorbidities.
  • For normal saline, the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 2,500mL for healthy patients and 750mL for those with cardiovascular disease.
  • If excessive absorption of fluid occurs with a hypotonic fluid; obtain serum electrolytes and the patient should be evaluated for volume overload.
  • Asymptomatic hyponatremia can be treated with fluid restriction and careful monitoring of urine output.
  • Treatment of symptomatic hyponatremia requires infusion of 3% sodium chloride and managed in intensive care.
  • Fluid overload from normal saline can be managed by fluid restriction; IV furosemide (20-40mg) is indicated if there is clinical or radiological evidence of pulmonary edema

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute tubular necrosis: While fluid overload can contribute to kidney injury, acute tubular necrosis is not the immediate complication in this scenario.

 

Option B. DIC: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a serious condition involving abnormal blood clotting but is not directly related to fluid overload from hysteroscopy.

 

Option D. Thromboembolism: Thromboembolism involves blood clots traveling to various parts of the body but is not the immediate consequence of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid overload during hysteroscopic surgery can lead to pulmonary edema as an immediate complication due to excessive absorption of uterine distension fluid.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a long history of chronic smoking presents to the clinic with respiratory symptoms. Upon examination, it is noted that the lining epithelium of his respiratory tract has undergone a notable change. The transition from columnar epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium is evident, as depicted in the provided image. To identify this specific change, what is the term used to describe this alteration in the lining epithelium? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metaplasia

 

The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

 

 

 

Metaplasia of normal columnar (left) to squamous epithelium (right) in a bronchus

 

  • Another example of metaplasia: BARRETTs esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysplasia: Dysplasia refers to abnormal development or growth of cells, tissues, or organs. It is characterized by changes in cell size, shape, and organization. Dysplasia can be a precursor to cancer but does not describe the replacement of one cell type by another.

 

Option B. Hypertrophy: Hypertrophy is the increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the tissue or organ. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Option C. Atrophy: Atrophy refers to the reduction in the size of cells, tissues, or organs, often due to decreased use, insufficient nutrition, or aging. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metaplasia is the term used to describe the reversible change where one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type, often as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as the transition from columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly with bone marrow having 22% plasma cells. The bone marrow biopsy had a pink acellular deposition of material as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amyloidosis

 

The patient’s clinical presentation, including hepatosplenomegaly and an increased number of plasma cells (22%) in the bone marrow, suggests a plasma cell dyscrasia, most likely multiple myeloma.

 

 In multiple myeloma, there is overproduction of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains, particularly lambda light chains, which can be deposited as amyloid fibrils.

 

The bone marrow biopsy showing pink acellular material confirms amyloidosis, a condition where these abnormal proteins are deposited in various tissues, including the liver and spleen, leading to organ dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow necrosis: This condition involves the death of bone marrow cells and would not present with acellular pink deposits seen in amyloidosis. It typically occurs due to severe conditions like leukemia or metastatic cancer.

 

Option B. T.B.: Tuberculosis affecting the bone marrow would present with granulomatous inflammation, not with a high percentage of plasma cells or acellular amyloid deposits.

 

Option C. Myxoid degeneration: This refers to a degenerative change within connective tissue, characterized by a gelatinous appearance. It does not cause acellular pink deposits and is not associated with increased plasma cells or amyloid formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloidosis can occur as a result of multiple myeloma due to the deposition of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains, which can be identified as acellular pink deposits on histology.

questions.text: A child presented with the following deformity and history of recurrent tooth abscess. On lab investigation, his serum calcium was normal, serum phosphorus was normal/reduced, serum PTH was normal, and ALP was increased. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A)  Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The key finding in this case is the normal PTH level. In metabolic bone disorders like rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) is often elevated, but in hypophosphatemic rickets, PTH remains normal. The patient also has normal/reduced serum phosphorus, which is another critical feature of hypophosphatemic rickets. Although serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is increased, this can also be seen in other forms of rickets, but the normal PTH differentiates this condition from others like nutritional rickets and Vitamin D-dependent rickets (VDDR). Additionally, recurrent tooth abscesses and bone deformities, as shown in the image, are typical clinical features of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Additional Information

 

Different type of Rickets:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nutritional rickets: In nutritional rickets, calcium may be normal to low, phosphorus is usually low, and PTH is typically elevated. This is inconsistent with the findings in the current case where PTH is normal.

 

Option C. VDDR 1 (Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 1): This condition involves a defect in the 1-alpha hydroxylation of Vitamin D, leading to low levels of active Vitamin D. Here, phosphorus is low, and PTH is elevated, which does not match the patient's normal PTH level.

 

Option D. VDDR 2 (Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2): In this condition, there is end-organ resistance to active Vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D), leading to high levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Phosphorus is low, and PTH is elevated, again differing from the normal PTH level observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by normal PTH levels, normal/reduced phosphorus levels, and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP). If PTH is normal in a case of suspected rickets, hypophosphatemic rickets should be strongly considered.

choices.text: Erect and real image is formed
Need to keep condenser close to patient’s eye

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Indirect Ophthalmoscopy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3-5x magnification is provided

 

Explanation:


Indirect ophthalmoscopy is a technique used to examine the fundus of the eye from a distance, typically at arm's length. It provides a stereoscopic (three-dimensional) view of the retina with a wide field of view, allowing visualization up to the ora serrata (peripheral retina). One of its key characteristics is the lower magnification compared to direct ophthalmoscopy.

 

Indirect ophthalmoscopy provides approximately 3-5x magnification of the fundus. This lower magnification is a trade-off for the wider field of view that it offers. The 20 diopter lens is most commonly used for indirect ophthalmoscopy, and the examination is typically performed with the patient in a lying position.

 

The indirect ophthalmoscope consists of a head-mounted light source and a handheld condensing lens (usually 20D). This setup creates an inverted and reverted real image between the observer and the condensing lens, providing binocular vision and excellent stereopsis, which helps in detecting elevations and depressions in the retina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erect and real image is formed: Incorrect. In indirect ophthalmoscopy, an inverted and real image is formed. This is in contrast to direct ophthalmoscopy, which produces an erect and virtual image. The inverted nature of the image in indirect ophthalmoscopy requires the examiner to mentally reorient the image for proper interpretation.

 

Option B. Need to keep condenser close to patient's eye: Incorrect. In indirect ophthalmoscopy, the examiner stays at a distance (around arm's length) from the patient, and the condensing lens is held approximately 1-2 inches in front of the patient's eye. This is in contrast to direct ophthalmoscopy, where the examiner needs to be close to the patient's eye (approximately 2-3 cm).

 

Option C. 15x magnification is provided: Incorrect. Direct ophthalmoscopy provides approximately 15x magnification, not indirect ophthalmoscopy. The higher magnification in direct ophthalmoscopy allows for detailed examination of small structures but limits the field of view compared to indirect ophthalmoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:


Indirect ophthalmoscopy provides a wide field of view with lower magnification (3-5x) compared to direct ophthalmoscopy, forming an inverted and real image that allows examination of the peripheral retina up to the ora serrata with good stereopsis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with pellagra-like symptoms. There was no history of flushing and urinary 5-HIAA levels were normal. Family history of similar illness was noted. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hartnup disease

 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective transport of neutral or non-polar amino acids, particularly tryptophan, in the intestines and kidneys. This defect leads to decreased absorption and increased urinary excretion of these amino acids, resulting in tryptophan deficiency. Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (vitamin B3), serotonin, and melatonin. Deficiency in tryptophan can therefore lead to niacin deficiency, manifesting as pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Unlike Fanconi syndrome, which is characterized by non-selective amino aciduria (excretion of various amino acids including proline, hydroxyproline, and arginine), Hartnup disease typically shows selective amino aciduria, primarily affecting tryptophan and similar neutral amino acids.

 

Key indicators in this case include:

 

  • Pellagra-like symptoms: Dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, commonly associated with niacin deficiency.
  • No history of flushing and normal urinary 5-HIAA levels: These findings rule out carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by flushing and elevated 5-HIAA levels due to serotonin overproduction.
  • Family history of similar illness: Suggests a genetic disorder, consistent with the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern of Hartnup disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid: Typically presents with flushing, diarrhea, and elevated urinary 5-HIAA levels due to serotonin overproduction. These findings are absent here.

 

Option C. Nutritional pellagra: Caused by dietary niacin deficiency. The presence of a family history of similar symptoms makes a genetic cause more likely than a nutritional deficiency.

 

Option D. Essential fructosuria: A benign condition caused by a defect in fructokinase, leading to fructose excretion in urine. It does not cause pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hartnup disease should be considered in patients with pellagra-like symptoms, particularly if there is a family history of similar symptoms and no evidence of carcinoid syndrome or nutritional deficiency. 

 

Elevated levels of neutral amino acids like tryptophan in the urine are a hallmark of Hartnup disease, indicating an issue with amino acid reabsorption in the kidneys.

questions.text: Which of the following plasma protein will decrease in acute inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

In the context of acute inflammation, most plasma proteins, known as acute-phase reactants, typically increase due to the influence of cytokines like interleukin-6 (IL-6) and interleukin-1 (IL-1). These are referred to as positive acute-phase reactants.

 

However, there are certain proteins, called negative acute-phase reactants, that decrease during acute inflammation. Albumin is one such protein. The decrease in albumin during inflammation is thought to help conserve amino acids for the production of more essential proteins needed during the inflammatory response. Additionally, lower albumin levels help to reduce blood viscosity and facilitate the movement of immune cells to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CRP: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a well-known positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels significantly increase during inflammation, making it a common marker for detecting inflammation.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: Hepcidin is another positive acute-phase reactant. It increases during inflammation and plays a role in iron metabolism, often contributing to the anemia seen in chronic disease.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Ferritin, an iron-storage protein, also acts as a positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels rise during inflammation, reflecting increased storage of iron in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative acute-phase reactants – Albumin, Transferrin, Transthyretin

 

Positive acute-phase reactants - CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin
